title: What has to happen to an object to be considered in motion? - Quora

response.answer_text: Motion is a relative term. Objects move in a reference frame—in other words, you (the observer) choose what point in space you consider to be the “static” base and then, if the object’s distance changes in time relative to that point, you say that the object moves. So, as you can see, absolutely nothing has to happen to that object. If you look at Earth while standing on it (considering yourself the “static” point of reference), the Earth doesn’t move (relative to you). But when you look at it from the Moon, you can see it moving. If you wanted to know what has to happen in order to make a previously static object move (in the same reference frame), then the answer is that a force must be applied. As the speed of it was 0 and now it’s not, the speed had to change. Change of speed in time is called acceleration. Acceleration is caused by application of force (in Newton’s classical mechanics). But you don’t need force to keep an object moving (unless it is decelerated, for example by friction). That’s what the 1st Newton’s law says. See Newton's laws of motion - Wikipedia.

(A) Nothing => if it already was in motion when you started observing it. (B) Depends on your frame of reference => not being in motion may be impossible. (C) A push or pull from a force may have increased its speed.
